name: Tonga
introduction: Tonga - unique among Pacific nations - never completely lost its indigenous governance. The archipelagos of "The Friendly Islands" were united into a Polynesian kingdom in 1845. Tonga became a constitutional monarchy in 1875 and a British protectorate in 1900; it withdrew from the protectorate and joined the Commonwealth of Nations in 1970. Tonga remains the only monarchy in the Pacific.

communications.phone_system_general_assessment: fair system based on a network of microwave radio relay routes supplemented by open-wire lines and a mobile-cellular system
communications.phone_system_international: country code - 228; satellite earth stations - 1 Intelsat (Atlantic Ocean), 1 Symphonie (2015)
communications.phone_system_domestic: microwave radio relay and open-wire lines for conventional system; combined fixed-line and mobile-cellular teledensity roughly 60 telephones per 100 persons with mobile-cellular use predominating
communications.broadcast_media: 2 state-owned TV stations with multiple transmission sites; 5 private TV stations broadcast locally; cable TV service is available; state-owned radio network with multiple stations; several dozen private radio stations and a few community radio stations; (2007)

economy.overview: This small, sub-Saharan economy depends heavily on both commercial and subsistence agriculture, which provides employment for a significant share of the labor force. Some basic foodstuffs must still be imported. Cocoa, coffee, and cotton generate about 40% of export earnings with cotton being the most important cash crop. Togo is among the world's largest producers of phosphate and seeks to develop its carbonate phosphate reserves. ++  ++ The government's decade-long effort, supported by the World Bank and the IMF, to implement economic reform measures, encourage foreign investment, and bring revenues in line with expenditures has moved slowly. Togo completed its IMF Extended Credit Facility in 2011 and reached a Heavily Indebted Poor Country debt relief completion point in 2010 at which 95% of the country's debt was forgiven. Togo continues to work with the IMF on structural reforms. Progress depends on follow through on privatization, increased openness in government financial operations, progress toward legislative elections, and continued support from foreign donors. ++  ++ Togoâ€™s 2015 economic growth remained steady at 5.4%, largely driven by infusions of foreign aid, infrastructure investment in the port and mineral sectors, and improvements in the business climate. Foreign direct investment inflows have slowed in recent years.
economy.gdp_power_parity: $11.61 billion (2016 est.) ++ $11.02 billion (2015 est.) ++ $10.46 billion (2014 est.)
economy.agriculture_products: coffee, cocoa, cotton, yams, cassava (manioc, tapioca), corn, beans, rice, millet, sorghum; livestock; fish
economy.industries: phosphate mining, agricultural processing, cement, handicrafts, textiles, beverages
economy.external_debt: $1.173 billion (31 December 2016 est.) ++ $1.034 billion (31 December 2015 est.)
economy.stock_money_narrow: $1.315 billion (31 December 2016 est.) ++ $1.14 billion (31 December 2015 est.)
economy.stock_money_broad: $2.599 billion (31 December 2016 est.) ++ $2.184 billion (31 December 2015 est.)
economy.stock_domestic_credit: $1.977 billion (31 December 2016 est.) ++ $1.65 billion (31 December 2015 est.)
economy.exports_partners: India 14.6%, Burkina Faso 11.3%, China 11.3%, Benin 9.6%, Ghana 9%, Lebanon 8.3%, Nigeria 6.1%, Niger 5.9% (2015)
economy.imports_commodities: machinery and equipment, foodstuffs, petroleum products
economy.imports_partners: China 22.9%, Belgium 20.3%, Netherlands 11.9%, France 6.6%, India 4.8%, Singapore 4.4% (2015)
economy.exchange_rates: Communaute Financiere Africaine francs (XOF) per US dollar - ++ 605.7 (2016 est.) ++ 591.45 (2015 est.) ++ 591.45 (2014 est.) ++ 494.42 (2013 est.) ++ 510.53 (2012 est.)

geography.location_description: Western Africa, bordering the Bight of Benin, between Benin and Ghana
geography.climate: tropical; hot, humid in south; semiarid in north
geography.terrain: gently rolling savanna in north; central hills; southern plateau; low coastal plain with extensive lagoons and marshes
geography.hazards: hot, dry harmattan wind can reduce visibility in north during winter; periodic droughts
geography.notes: the country's length allows it to stretch through six distinct geographic regions; climate varies from tropical to savanna

government.name: Togolese Republic
government.name_etymology: derived from the Ewe words "to" (water) and "go" (shore) to give the sense of "by the water"; originally, this designation applied to the town of Togo (now Togoville) on the northern shore of Lake Togo, but the name was eventually extended to the entire nation
government.capital_time_zone: UTC 0 (5 hours ahead of Washington, DC, during Standard Time)
government.administrative_divisions: 5 regions (regions, singular - region); Centrale, Kara, Maritime, Plateaux, Savanes
government.constitution: several previous; latest adopted 27 September 1992, effective 14 October 1992; amended 2002, 2007 (2016)
government.executive_cabinet: Council of Ministers appointed by the president on the advice of the prime minister
government.executive_elections: president directly elected by simple majority popular vote for a 5-year term (no term limits); election last held on 25 April 2015 (next to be held in 2020); prime minister appointed by the president
government.executive_election_results: Faure GNASSINGBE reelected president; percent of vote - Faure GNASSINGBE (UNIR) 58.8%, Jean-Pierre FABRE (ANC) 35.2%, Tchaboure GOGUE 4%, other 2%
government.legislative_description: unicameral National Assembly or Assemblee Nationale (91 seats; members directly elected in multi-seat constituencies by proportional representation vote to serve 5-year terms)
government.legislative_elections: last held on 25 July 2013 (next to be held in 2018)
government.legislative_election_results: percent of vote by party - UNIR 46.7%, CST 28.9%, Rainbow Alliance 10.8%, UFC 7.7%, independent 0.8%, other 5.1%; seats by party - UNIR 62, CST 19, Rainbow Alliance 6, UFC 3, independent 1
government.legislative_highest_courts: Supreme Court or Cour Supreme (organized into criminal and administrative chambers, each with a chamber president and advisors); Constitutional Court (consists of 9 judges including the court president)
government.legislative_judge_selection: Supreme Court president appointed by decree of the president of the republic upon the proposal of the Supreme Council of the Magistracy, a 9-member judicial, advisory, and disciplinary body; other judge appointments and judge tenure NA; Constitutional Court judges appointed by the National Assembly; judge tenure NA
government.legislative_subordinate_courts: Court of Assizes (sessions court); Appeal Court; tribunals of first instance (divided into civil, commercial, and correctional chambers; Court of State Security; military tribunal
government.political_parties: Action Committee for Renewal or CAR [Dodji APEVON] ++ Democratic Convention of African Peoples or CDPA [Brigitte ADJAMAGBO-JOHNSON] ++ National Alliance for Change or ANC [Jean-Pierre FABRE] ++ Pan-African Patriotic Convergence or CPP [Edem KODJO] ++ Rainbow Alliance (a coalition including CAR and CDPA) [Brigitte ADJAMAGBO-JOHNSON] ++ Save Togo Collective or CST (a coalition including: ANC and PSR) [Ata Messan Zeus AJAVON ++ Socialist Pact for Renewal or PSR [Abi TCHESSA] ++ Union for Democracy and Social Progress or UDPS [Gagou KOKOU] ++ Union of Forces for Change or UFC [Gilchrist OLYMPIO] ++ Union for the Republic or UNIR [Faure GNASSINGBE]
government.international_organization_participation: ACP, AfDB, AU, ECOWAS, EITI (compliant country), Entente, FAO, FZ, G-77, IAEA, IBRD, ICAO, ICRM, IDA, IDB, IFAD, IFC, IFRCS, ILO, IMF, IMO, Interpol, IOC, IOM, IPU, ISO (correspondent), ITSO, ITU, ITUC (NGOs), MIGA, MINURSO, MINUSMA, NAM, OIC, OIF, OPCW, PCA, UN, UNAMID, UNCTAD, UNESCO, UNHCR, UNIDO, UNMIL, UNOCI, UNWTO, UPU, WADB (regional), WAEMU, WCO, WFTU (NGOs), WHO, WIPO, WMO, WTO
government.flag_description: five equal horizontal bands of green (top and bottom) alternating with yellow; a white five-pointed star on a red square is in the upper hoist-side corner; the five horizontal stripes stand for the five different regions of the country; the red square is meant to express the loyalty and patriotism of the people; green symbolizes hope, fertility, and agriculture; yellow represents mineral wealth and faith that hard work and strength will bring prosperity; the star symbolizes life, purity, peace, dignity, and Togo's independence
government.national_symbols: lion; national colors: green, yellow, red, white

issues.international_disputes: in 2001, Benin claimed Togo moved boundary monuments - joint commission continues to resurvey the boundary; talks continue between Benin and Togo on funding the Adjrala hydroelectric dam on the Mona River
issues.illicit_drugs: transit hub for Nigerian heroin and cocaine traffickers; money laundering not a significant problem
issues.refugees: in 2001, Benin claimed Togo moved boundary monuments - joint commission continues to resurvey the boundary; talks continue between Benin and Togo on funding the Adjrala hydroelectric dam on the Mona River

people.literacy_definition: age 15 and over can read and write
